channel.title: Using injected interfaces
channel.description: I have a question about making a bot.. I have the bot part set, and I have an adequate updater. Now, how do you get an instance of the implementing class. For example, if I have a "Player" interface, how do I get an instance of the class that "Player" is.

item.title: Using injected interfaces
item.dc:creator: @niothiel niothiel
item.description:
@niothiel wrote:

Oh, so I really don’t need instances of the given class, they are all static somewhere, and if not, they are contained in the static class… I got it, I fully understand now. Thank you so much for putting up with my nagging. Please close this topic.

Read full topic

item.title: Using injected interfaces
item.dc:creator: @semaphore semaphore
item.description:
@semaphore wrote:

I cannot think of a more concise way to explain it than iamadam did.

You need to create a DAO that returns the objects you need. (That is typically where you have to lift a finger and do something yourself instead of leeching).

Aside from what iamadam said… I really cannot think of any other way to explain it to you in a way that would make it clearer.

Read full topic

item.title: Using injected interfaces
item.dc:creator: @niothiel niothiel
item.description:
@niothiel wrote:

I know how an interface works. But in order to be able to use the methods in the interface, you need an INSTANCE of the IMPLEMENTING class, which I have a problem with obtaining. Once I do have it, I can simply cast the class instance into the interface and use the interface’s methods. But I need a CLASS INSTANCE for that. The only one I have obtained so far is the client instance.

Read full topic

item.title: Using injected interfaces
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

learn what the point of an interface is.

why did you post this here as well as rsr anwyay?

Read full topic

item.title: Using injected interfaces
item.dc:creator: @niothiel niothiel
item.description:
@niothiel wrote:

I know, but if I injected the interface into a different class? In addition to the client class?

Read full topic

item.title: Using injected interfaces
item.dc:creator: @Aftermath_961 Aftermath
item.description:
@Aftermath_961 wrote:

niothiel:

How do I get the class so I can cast it? I have an instance of client, but that’s it. It would sort of make sense if you could access static variables without an instance, but if it’s private, client doesn’t have the scope to look through the given class’s private fields, therefore making a get injected into client not viable.

If you have an instance of the client, that’s all you need. If you injected the interface, then just do:

((InjectedInterfaceName) clientInstance).injectedMethod();

Read full topic

item.title: Using injected interfaces
item.dc:creator: @niothiel niothiel
item.description:
@niothiel wrote:

How do I get the class so I can cast it? I have an instance of client, but that’s it. It would sort of make sense if you could access static variables without an instance, but if it’s private, client doesn’t have the scope to look through the given class’s private fields, therefore making a get injected into client not viable.

item.title: Using injected interfaces
item.dc:creator: @Aftermath_961 Aftermath
item.description:
@Aftermath_961 wrote:

Cast the class to your injected interface and then use the method you injected,

Read full topic

item.title: Using injected interfaces
item.dc:creator: @Iamadam Iamadam
item.description:
@Iamadam wrote:

Make client implement your client interface. Then inject getters to the client.

public Player[] getPlayers() { return ab.c; }
Then:

Player[] players = myClientReference.getPlayers();

Read full topic
